Award.AbstractNarration:
Abelian varieties are at the same time algebraic varieties (spaces described by polynomial equations) and abelian groups (sets with an operation that obeys the same laws as addition on the set of whole numbers), and what makes them interesting to a mathematician is the interplay between those two structures. They have been intensively studied since the 19th century, especially in the field of algebraic geometry, but many important questions remain unsolved. This project will take a new approach to some of those questions, by investigating the properties of D-modules on abelian varieties. D-modules are basically systems of partial differential equations, in an abstract form that is useful for studying geometric questions. For example, whenever one has a mapping from another algebraic variety to an abelian variety, one gets a certain number of D-modules on the abelian variety that contain information about the original mapping. The main new idea is that interesting properties of these (and other) D-modules on abelian varieties can be revealed with the help of Fourier analysis, in the same way that interesting properties of signals (such as sound waves) can be revealed by looking at their frequency spectrum. The hope is that a good understanding of the "spectrum" of D-modules on abelian varieties will lead to new results about their geometry.

In more technical language, the research objective of the project is to give a complete characterization of Fourier-Mukai transforms of holonomic D-modules on complex abelian varieties. These transforms are complexes of coherent sheaves on the moduli space of line bundles with connection (which is a hyperkaehler manifold), and in many ways, they look remarkably similar to perverse sheaves. This suggests that Fourier-Mukai transforms of holonomic D-modules should make up an as-yet conjectural category of "hyperkaehler perverse sheaves"; the project will make this idea precise and test some of its implications. This question is also of practical interest, because it provides a new tool for solving problems about abelian varieties and irregular varieties, similar to the generic vanishing theorem of Green and Lazarsfeld. A second objective is to make the theory of mixed Hodge modules more widely known. Building on a recent Clay Mathematics Institute workshop, the PI and others plan to write a book about mixed Hodge modules and their applications that will try to make this powerful theory accessible to non-experts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of D-modules, introduced by Sato and Kashiwara in the 1970s in order to study systems of linear partial differential equations, has since found many applications in algebraic geometry, representation theory, and Hodge theory. The idea is to view such a system on a complex manifold as a sheaf of modules over the sheaf of linear differential operators, and to study it by geometric and algebraic methods. The situation is similar to complex analysis, where Cartan, Oka, and Serre discovered that it is useful to view systems of linear equations with holomorphic coefficients as sheaves of modules over the sheaf of holomorphic functions.

The most important class of D-modules are the regular holonomic ones: a holonomic D-module is essentially a holomorphic vector bundle with an integrable connection that is allowed to have singularities at certain points, and regularity is a condition on the singularities. Kashiwara and Mebkhout showed that the category of regular holonomic D-modules is equivalent to the category of perverse sheaves; this "Riemann-Hilbert correspondence" is a far-reaching generalization of the fact that a holomorphic vector bundle with an integrable connection is equivalent to a local system, and thus to a representation of the fundamental group. The subtle links between analysis and topology that come out of this correspondence make D-modules very useful in geometry. The Riemann-Hilbert correspondence is also the basis of Morihiko Saito’s theory of mixed Hodge modules, which extends Hodge theory to a certain class of regular holonomic D-modules.

The goal of this proposal was to understand holonomic D-modules on abelian varieties (and related questions having to do with "generic vanishing"), and to write a more accessible treatment of the theory of mixed Hodge modules. In joint work with Bhatt and Scholze, the PI gave alternative proofs for the "generic vanishing" results for perverse sheaves (and regular holonomic D-modules) on abelian varieties. Together with Pareschi and Popa, the PI extended the known results in generic vanishing theory from smooth projective varieties to all compact Kaehler manifolds, through the use of Hodge modules. This work, and joint work by Popa and the PI about direct images of pluricanonical bundles, formed the basis for a joint paper of Lombardi, Popa, and the PI, in which generic vanishing theory was extended to pluricanonical bundles (which had been out of reach of earlier techniques). Popa and the PI also used Hodge modules to prove Viehweg's hyperbolicity conjecture for families of varieties of general type with maximal variation in birational moduli. One ingredient in the proof was a result by Campana and Paun (about pseudo-effectivity of quotients of tensor powers of the log cotangent bundle), and the PI found a simplified proof of this result. Finally, the PI found a better definition for Mukai's Fourier transform (which relates the derived category of coherent sheaves on an abelian variety to that on the dual abelian variety) that greatly simplifies many of the results in generic vanishing theory.

Concerning broader impacts, the PI has tried to make the theory of mixed Hodge modules more accessible in several ways. First, together with Mark de Cataldo and Radu Laza, the PI organized a semester-long program about "Complex, p-adic, and log Hodge theory" (Simons Center for Geometry and Physics, Spring 2016). The PI also served on the scientific committee for the 2019 "JAVA" school on Tatihou island, whose topic was Mixed Hodge Modules and Applications. Together with Claude Sabbah, the PI has been working on a (very long) project to generalize the theory of mixed Hodge modules to the case of complex coefficients, and to write an account of the resulting theory that is accessible to graduate students; the current version can be found online:

http://www.cmls.polytechnique.fr/perso/sabbah.claude/MHMProject/mhm.html

The new theory is based entirely on D-module theory, without any mention of perverse sheaves, and the main technical point is to describe polarizations as distribution-valued pairings between D-modules. This requires, among many other things, reproving the existing results (by Schmid and others) on degenerating variations of Hodge structure; the PI is currently writing up a simplified account of this theory in dimension one, as part of a graduate course at Stony Brook. The PI is advising three graduate students, who work on topics in Hodge theory, and the PI has organized a significant number of general activities in his department (such as a "Math Day" for undergraduate students, a professional development seminar for graduate students and postdocs, several series of short self-introduction talks by finishing graduate students and incoming postdocs, etc.).
